awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Investigating Ion-transport and Dynamics in Composite Materials Containing Large Boron-rich Anion (LBRA) Salts
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  In this project, funded by the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate and housed in the Chemistry Division, Professor Joseph Teprovich and his students at California State University Northridge (CSUN) will perform studies that aim to improve our understanding of electrolyte combinations so that lithium-ion batteries that are more efficient and have longer lifetimes can be developed.  Prof. Teprovich will also incorporate a new course into the curriculum at CSUN in order to educate a diverse group of students about the Chemistry of Energy, and he will facilitate research experiences that are directly related to desirable career choices in STEM for underrepresented students.

Professor Teprovich will systematically investigate large boron-rich anions (LBRA) as alternatives for PF6- and other common anions in electrolyte systems, with the goal of understanding and achieving high cation translational mobility while simultaneously reducing anion translational mobility. Two approaches, nanoionic destabilization and anion trapping, will be used to minimize the translational mobility of the LBRA.  A plan for broadening participation is presented that is centered around the high underrepresented minority (URM) student populations at CSUN, which is both a Hispanic Serving Institution (HIS) and an Asian American, Native American, Pacific Islander-Serving Institution (AANAPISI).  A main feature of the broadening participation plan is development of a summer STEM program for local high school students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The LEAPS-MPS program supported research activities to understand a new and emerging class of electrolytes (large boron-rich anion (LBRA) salts) for multiple battery chemistries at California State University Northridge (CSUN).  CSUN is designated as a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI).  The research findings from this project highlighted the potential future importance LBRA salts as building blocks for new and safer battery chemistries that do not rely on supply chain sensitive materials.  The program provided an opportunity for 10 students at CSUN (8 undergraduate and 2 Masters students) to perform hand-on research activities and gain knowledge/skills not encountered in the typical chemistry course sequence.  This includes the development of advanced in-situ spectroscopic techniques to monitor battery chemistry in real time (see associated image), electrochemical testing of battery materials, and the synthesis of novel electrolyte composite materials.  Research activities from this project led to 3 publications in high ranking journals (Advanced Science, ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, and Applied Sciences) with these students as coauthors. This enabled the participating students to pursue jobs in industry or pursue a Ph.D at an R1 university.  An additional 2 publications from this research project are expected in the upcoming year.  Students and the project PI were able to present this research at multiple local, national, and international conferences.  Some of the students received awards for their research presentation at these conferences and the PI gave 6 invited lectures based on this research. 

The LEAPS-MPS program also facilitated additional opportunities for students at CSUN, not directly involved in the research activities, to gain skills and knowledge via a newly created graduate class called Chemistry of Energy.  A laboratory course for this class was also created and allowed students to fabricate devices and perform experiments on supercapacitors, lithium ion batteries, solar cells, and electrolytic CO2 conversion.  These two courses will become regularly offered courses in the department and are open to both undergraduate and graduate students.  The program also provided an opportunity for local high school students and their parents to learn about science through a CSUN chemistry open house program that was developed.  This open house program consisted of large scale chemistry demos followed by a hands-on portion in which the high school students were able to perform experiments in our chemistry labs.  During the two years the chemistry open house program was offered, over 140 students and parents from the local community participated (see attached images from the 2023 and 2024 events).  Based on the popularity of the event with the participants, we will continue to offer this chemistry open house program for the local community.


Last Modified: 03/12/2025
Modified by: Joseph A Teprovich

The LEAPS-MPS program supported research activities to understand a new and emerging class of electrolytes (large boron-rich anion (LBRA) salts) for multiple battery chemistries at California State University Northridge (CSUN). CSUN is designated as a Hispanic Serving Institution (HSI). The research findings from this project highlighted the potential future importance LBRA salts as building blocks for new and safer battery chemistries that do not rely on supply chain sensitive materials. The program provided an opportunity for 10 students at CSUN (8 undergraduate and 2 Masters students) to perform hand-on research activities and gain knowledge/skills not encountered in the typical chemistry course sequence. This includes the development of advanced in-situ spectroscopic techniques to monitor battery chemistry in real time (see associated image), electrochemical testing of battery materials, and the synthesis of novel electrolyte composite materials. Research activities from this project led to 3 publications in high ranking journals (Advanced Science, ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces, and Applied Sciences) with these students as coauthors. This enabled the participating students to pursue jobs in industry or pursue a Ph.D at an R1 university. An additional 2 publications from this research project are expected in the upcoming year. Students and the project PI were able to present this research at multiple local, national, and international conferences. Some of the students received awards for their research presentation at these conferences and the PI gave 6 invited lectures based on this research.


The LEAPS-MPS program also facilitated additional opportunities for students at CSUN, not directly involved in the research activities, to gain skills and knowledge via a newly created graduate class called Chemistry of Energy. A laboratory course for this class was also created and allowed students to fabricate devices and perform experiments on supercapacitors, lithium ion batteries, solar cells, and electrolytic CO2 conversion. These two courses will become regularly offered courses in the department and are open to both undergraduate and graduate students. The program also provided an opportunity for local high school students and their parents to learn about science through a CSUN chemistry open house program that was developed. This open house program consisted of large scale chemistry demos followed by a hands-on portion in which the high school students were able to perform experiments in our chemistry labs. During the two years the chemistry open house program was offered, over 140 students and parents from the local community participated (see attached images from the 2023 and 2024 events).
